newsitem.title: YEMEN: Saudi and Yemen open new round of border talks.
newsitem.headline: Saudi and Yemen open new round of border talks.

text.p: Saudi Arabia and Yemen on Sunday began a new round of talks in Sanaa aimed at settling a long-standing border dispute, a Yemeni official said.
Officials from both sides were due to discuss issues related to the demarcation of the border between oil giant Saudi Arabia and Yemen, he said.
Yemen has hinted it might resort to international arbitration if more than a year of talks with Saudi Arabia fail to settle the 60-year-old border dispute.
Saudi Arabia and Yemen had several minor clashes in a border area potentially rich in oil and gas before the two sides signed a memorandum of understanding in 1995 to resolve the dispute.
Yemen's President Ali Abdullah Saleh had in the summer complained that the committee was making slow progress and called for a summit with Saudi Arabia to speed up the talks.
The committee has met scores of times since 1995.

Yemen's relations with Gulf Arab states, including Saudi Arabia, have improved in the last few years. Sanaa angered Gulf Arab governments when it appeared to side with Iraq during the 1990-91 Gulf crisis over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
